bcl:text.#text:
means coal land reserved under section
          21;

means the area of land specified in a licence or
          lease;
means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the government for land owned by the government,

a person registered in the land title office as the registered owner of the
            surface area or as its purchaser under an agreement for sale, and

bcl:text.#text: a person to whom a disposition of Crown land has been issued under the ;

means mining and removing coal for use, marketing or
          sale;
has the meaning in the ;
means surface area of land;
means a unit as defined under the .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Right of entry of recorded holder

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A recorded holder may enter, occupy and use coal land and prospect for, explore
          for, develop and produce coal.

The right of entry under subsection (1) does not extend to any of the
          following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: land occupied by a building;
the curtilage of a dwelling house;

protected heritage property, except as authorized by the minister or local
            government responsible for the protection of the heritage property;
orchard land;
land under cultivation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Unless the location is one of the following, a land use designation or objective
          does not preclude application by a recorded holder for any form of permission, or approval
          of that permission, required in relation to mining activity by the recorded
          holder:

bcl:text.#text: an area in which mining is prohibited under the ;

a park under the  or a regional park under the
            ;

bcl:link.in:doc:
Protected Areas of
                British Columbia Act

bcl:text.#text: a park or ecological reserve under the ;
an ecological reserve under the ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an area of Crown land if

bcl:text.#text: the area is designated under section 93.1 of the  for a purpose under that section, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text:
the order under that section making the designation, or an amendment to the
              order, precludes the application by the recorded holder;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a protected heritage property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Despite this or any other Act, the minister may restrict the use of surface rights
          by a person who holds a licence if, after inspection and giving reasonable notice to that
          person, the minister considers that the surface area is so situated that it should be used
          for purposes other than mining.

If surface rights are restricted under subsection (4), the minister must
          serve the licensee with a notice of the restriction.

No compensation is payable as a result of a restriction under subsection
          (4).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Right of entry on private land and compensation

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A recorded holder must not begin the exploration for or development or production
          of coal unless the recorded holder first gives notice, in the prescribed form and manner
          and within the prescribed period, to every owner of surface area on which the recorded
          holder intends to carry out that activity.

A recorded holder is liable to pay compensation to the owners of surface area for
          loss or damage caused by the recorded holder entering, occupying or using the surface
          area.

bcl:text.#text:
On application of a recorded holder or owner, the Surface Rights Board under the
             has authority to settle
          disputes arising from rights acquired under this Act in respect of entry, use or
          occupation, security, rent and compensation and, for this purpose, Parts 16 and
            17 of the
             apply.

In an arbitration under subsection (3) involving a conflict between rights
          acquired under this Act and rights acquired under the , the Surface Rights Board must take into account which of the
          rights were applied for first and must give the holder of those rights some priority in
          its consideration of the dispute between the parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A copy of an order made by the Surface Rights Board under subsection (3)
          may be filed at any time in a Supreme Court registry and enforced as if it were an order
          of the court.

bcl:text.#text:
If, after the coming into force of this section, the minister responsible for the
          administration of the  expropriates under section 11 of
          the  the rights of the licensee under a licence or of
          the lessee under a lease, compensation is payable to the licensee or lessee, as the case
          may be, in an amount equal to the value of the rights expropriated, to be determined under
          the regulations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If the minister responsible for the administration of this Act and the licensee or
          lessee, as the case may be, do not agree as to the amount of compensation that is payable
          under subsection
            (1), the minister, the licensee or the lessee may require the dispute to be
          settled by a single arbitrator who has the prescribed qualifications and is to be
          appointed by the minister.

The award of the single arbitrator appointed by the minister responsible for the
          administration of this Act is binding on the parties to the arbitration.

A recorded holder may surrender any of the following by notifying the
          minister:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a licence or part of a licence;
a lease or part of a lease.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A refund of fees or rentals must not be paid as a result of a surrender under
            subsection
            (1).

A provision in a disposition by a recorded holder that has the effect of dividing
          the interest in the licence or lease on the basis of the stratification, physical position
          or characteristics of the coal under the location is void.

A grantee under a disposition of a licence or lease, or part of it,
          must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
record the document effecting the disposition with the chief gold commissioner,
            and

pay for the recording a fee the Lieutenant Governor in Council may
            prescribe.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
As between the parties to a document referred to in subsection (2), failure to record
          the document does not invalidate the document.

A disposition of a licence or lease, or of an interest in either of them, is not
          enforceable and must not be recorded unless the disposition is in writing and signed by
          the transferor or by the transferor's agent as authorized in writing.

If a licence or lease expires, is surrendered or is cancelled under this Act, the
          former licensee or former lessee, not more than 12 months after the date of the expiry,
          surrender or cancellation, and subject to the consent of the chief gold commissioner, may
          enter the location and remove any mining plant, machinery, personal property and other
          material placed by the former licensee or former lessee on the location.

bcl:text.#text:
If a licensee or lessee has complied with this Act, the regulations and the
          licence or lease and paid to the government all money due by the licensee or lessee under
          this Act and the , the chief gold commissioner
          must not refuse to consent.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Any mining plant, machinery, personal property or other material not removed
          within the 12 month period specified in subsection (1) is vested in the government on order of
          the chief gold commissioner, and the chief gold commissioner, on behalf of the government,
          may take possession of and sell it or otherwise dispose of it subject to the terms the
          chief gold commissioner considers appropriate.

A licensee, a lessee or a person exploring for, developing or producing coal on
          land other than coal land, must submit to the minister the information or data required by
          regulation, respecting the exploration, development and production of coal.

If a licence or lease expires, is surrendered or is cancelled under this Act, the
          licensee or lessee, not more than 90 days after the date of the expiry, surrender or
          cancellation, must submit to the minister the information or data required under subsection (1)
          as if the licence or lease were valid and subsisting.
A licensee, under this Act and the licence, has the exclusive rights

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to explore for and develop coal on the licence location, and

bcl:text.#text:
with the approval of the chief inspector appointed under the , to mine and remove those quantities of coal the licensee
            may reasonably require for testing, to a maximum of 100 000 tonnes.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A licensee is entitled to explore for and develop only the coal that is inside the
          boundaries, continued vertically downward, of the licence location.
The holder of a licence is entitled

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
to enter, occupy and use the surface area of the location for the purpose of
            exploring for and developing coal on the location,

bcl:text.#text:
subject to entering into an agreement in the form of a free use permit under the
               or a licence to cut under that Act, to use
            and remove timber that, at the time the holder of the licence enters into the agreement,
            is on the location, and

to the non-exclusive right to use sand, gravel and rock from the location for
            use on the location for a construction purpose approved under the , without the necessity of obtaining under the  a licence, lease, permit or other authorization.

bcl:link.in:doc:
Forest Practices Code of
              British Columbia Act

bcl:text.#text:
A licensee must be issued a special use permit under the , subject to any terms and conditions set by
          the issuing authority, for the construction of appropriate access to the area of that
          licence for mining exploration, if the licensee
is the holder of a permit under the  for the mining exploration,

bcl:link.in:doc:
Forest Practices Code of British Columbia
              Act

bcl:text.#text:
applies for and receives the written approval of the Chief Inspector of Mines to
            the issue under the  of the special use permit, and

bcl:link.in:doc:
Forest Practices Code of British Columbia
              Act

bcl:text.#text: applies under the  for the special use permit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
For the purpose of this section, the Chief Inspector of Mines, after considering
          practicable alternative means of access, may grant or refuse the written approval referred
          to in subsection
            (1) (b).

bcl:text.#text:
The boundaries of every new or amended licence location must conform to the
          regulations under the  that
          define the petroleum and natural gas grid, unless the minister orders
          otherwise.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A licence location must be located or must be acquired from the government in
          accordance with the regulations.

The licence location must consist of adjoining units and must not include more
          than 20 units.

A recorded holder, by notifying the minister, may reduce the size of the licence
          location as prescribed by regulation.

The recorded holder is not entitled to any compensation or refund of the annual
          rental as a result of reducing the size of a licence location under subsection
          (4).

A person may apply to the minister for a licence, in the form and manner the
          minister specifies.
An application must be accompanied by all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the prescribed application fee;
a prescribed rent in respect of the location;
a plan and description of the location under section 11.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
On receipt of an application that complies with subsection (2), the minister may
          issue a licence to the applicant containing terms and conditions required by the
          minister.

If the minister does not issue a licence, the minister must refund the rent paid
          under subsection
            (2) (b).
A licence is valid for a term of one year from the date of its issue.

If a licensee complies during the term of the licence with every provision of this
          Act and the licence, the minister, on application by the licensee under this section, must
          extend the term of the licence for further one year terms.

The application must be made before the licence expires and must be accompanied by
          all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a prescribed rent in respect of the location;
the information and data required under section 8 (1).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If an application is made under subsection (2) and the licensee satisfies the
          minister that it is impracticable to file the information and data required under
            subsection (3)
            (b), the minister may allow the licensee to file the information and data
          during a period not exceeding 90 days from the date of the application.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
If a licensee has not applied under section 13 (2) to extend the term of
        the licence, the licensee, not more than 30 days after the date the licence expires and on
        payment of the prescribed late application fee, may apply under section 13 (2) to
        extend the term of the licence.

On application of a licensee, the minister may change the anniversary date of a
        licence, and if the minister changes the date, the rent must be prorated for the terms
        affected by the change.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Subject to subsection (2), a lessee has the exclusive right, in
          accordance with this Act and the lease, to explore for, develop and produce coal on the
          lease location.

Subject to subsection (3), a lessee does not acquire, under the
          lease, any right, title or interest in the surface area of the lease location.

If the surface area of a lease location is owned by the government and is used or
          occupied by the lessee, the lessee is entitled

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
to enter, occupy and use the surface area of the location to produce
            coal,

bcl:text.#text:
subject to entering into an agreement in the form of a free use permit under the
               or a licence to cut under that Act, to use
            and remove timber that, at the time the holder of the lease enters into the agreement,
            is on the location, and

to the non-exclusive right to use sand, gravel and rock from the location for
            use on the location for a construction purpose approved under the , without the necessity of obtaining under the  a licence, lease, permit or other authorization.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The boundaries of a lease location must conform to the boundaries of licence
          locations.
The lease location may contain one or more units.
The minister may require an applicant under section 18

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
to have the lease location surveyed by a British Columbia land surveyor,
            and

to file a copy of the survey notes and plots of the survey with the Surveyor
            General.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A licensee or lessee may apply for a lease, in the form and manner the minister
          specifies.

An application under subsection (1) must be made to the minister and must be
          accompanied by all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the prescribed application fee;
a prescribed rent in respect of the location;
a plan and description of the location under section 17;

a plan of operations showing the exploration, development and production to be
            carried out on the location during the term of the lease, supported by the data,
            feasibility studies and other information the minister may require to evaluate the
            application.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If the minister is satisfied that the application is made in accordance with
            subsections
            (1) and (2), the minister must issue a lease, containing terms
          and conditions required by the minister, to the applicant.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Term, extension and amendment of lease

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Subject to a contrary provision in this Act, a lease is valid for the term
          requested by the applicant, not to exceed 30 years from the date of its issue.

If a lessee complies during the term of the lease with every provision of this Act
          and the lease, the minister, on application by the lessee under this section, must extend
          the lease for terms requested by the lessee, not to exceed 15 years from the date the
          extension is issued.

An application under subsection (2) must be made before the term of the lease
          expires, in the form and manner the minister specifies, and must be accompanied by all of
          the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the application fee, if prescribed;
a prescribed rent in respect of the location;

the information or data the minister requires to evaluate the
            application.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Despite any provision of a lease and on the request of the recorded holder, the
          minister may extend the term of a lease subject to the terms and conditions respecting the
          extension that the minister considers appropriate.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
A lessee must pay to the government, in advance of the year for which it is payable,
        a prescribed rent in respect of the location.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The chief gold commissioner, by regulation, may designate an area of coal land as
          a coal land reserve.

Unless a regulation designating coal land as a coal land reserve provides
          otherwise,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
a person must not explore for, develop or produce coal on a coal land reserve,
            and
a licence or lease must not be issued for a coal land reserve.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The chief gold commissioner, by regulation, may cancel at any time all or part of
          a coal land reserve subject to the terms and conditions the chief gold commissioner
          prescribes.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote:
Recorded holder must notify of change of permanent
        address
bcl:section.bcl:text:
A recorded holder must notify the chief gold commissioner of a change in the
        holder's permanent address.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If service of a notice, an order or another document is required under this Act,
          the notice, order or document is deemed to have been served

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if served on the person, or
if sent by registered mail to the last known address of the person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If service is by registered mail, the notice, order or other document is deemed to
          be served on the eighth day after posting.
This section does not apply if a court orders another mode of service.

bcl:text.#text:
The Association of British Columbia Land Surveyors may make rules under section 75 of the
           respecting the surveying of land and
        locations under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If a recorded holder does not comply with any of the following, the minister may
          notify the recorded holder by registered mail of the failure to comply and may require the
          recorded holder to comply within the period specified in the notice:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: this Act or a licence or lease under it;

bcl:text.#text:
the  or a permit under
            it.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If the failure to comply is not remedied to the satisfaction of the minister
          within the time specified in a notice under subsection (1), the minister, by
          order, may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
suspend the operations of the recorded holder until the default is
            remedied,

refuse to renew any licence or lease held by the recorded holder until the
            recorded holder complies, and

after the failure of the recorded holder to remedy the default during a period
            of suspension ordered under paragraph (a), cancel the licence or lease.

bcl:text.#text:
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations referred to in section 41 of the
            .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may
          make regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
respecting the transportation, storage, use, examination and analysis of core
            samples;

respecting the confidentiality of information required to be supplied under the
            regulations;
respecting notices and periods for the purposes of section 3 (1);
for the purposes of section 4,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: determining value and defining the components that comprise value,

prescribing methods of evaluation for use in determining value, that may
              differ according to different components of value,
prescribing factors to be taken into account in an evaluation,

defining the role of evaluators in a determination of value and prescribing
              qualifications for evaluators that are prerequisite to their participation in the
              determination of value, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
respecting the submission of reports to the minister relating to coal
            exploration activities;

respecting fees and rentals to be paid under this Act and the method of
            calculating fees and rentals;

respecting units and coal licences, including a reduction in the size of a
            licence;
defining a word or phrase used but not defined in this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The minister, by order, may establish any form required, and any procedural rule
          for the use of a form required, under this Act.

If the minister considers that a person, through no fault of the person, is
          unjustly prejudiced by a time limit or requirement under this Act, the minister, by order,
          may extend the time limit whether or not it has expired.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person commits an offence who does any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: explores for, develops or produces coal other than under this Act;
contravenes a provision of this Act or the regulations;
refuses to submit any information required under this Act;

makes, assents to or acquiesces in making a false or deceptive return of any
          information required under this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote:
Transition for leases issued under section 24 of the former
        Act

bcl:text.#text: In this section,  means the , R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 51.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Section
            19 of this Act does not apply to a lease issued under section 24 of
          the former Act.

A lease issued under section 24 of the former Act must not be renewed and no
          compensation is payable for the loss of any right to renew the lease.

Subsection (3) does not prevent a person from applying under section 12 of
          this Act for a licence, or under section 18 of this Act for a lease, in respect of a
          location for which the person held a lease under section 24 of the former
          Act.

This section is repealed on a date to be set by regulation of the Lieutenant
          Governor in Council.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
The provisions of this Act referred to in column 1 of the following table come into
        force as set out in column 2 of the table:

oasis:entry.oasis:line: Anything not elsewhere covered by this table
By regulation of the Lieutenant Governor in Council

oasis:line.#text: On the coming into force of section 7 of the , S.B.C. 2003, c. 74

oasis:entry.oasis:line: By regulation of the Lieutenant Governor in Council
By regulation of the Lieutenant Governor in Council
By regulation of the Lieutenant Governor in Council

bcl:editorialnote.in:em: [Note: See Table of Legislative Changes for the status of these provisions.]
